instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.P3V3S4_EN: What is P3V3S4_EN? P3V3S4_EN is a signal that enables the PP3V3_S4 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message:
Hello Guys,

I have here a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that is not properly working. It almost works with both battery and DC in connected. Apple logo would show for 5 seconds with loading bar, computer restarts, repeats. Green light on charger and fan spin.

When everything is disconnected and only the DC in adaptor is plugged in, it is stuck on an S5 state:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present + green light on charger
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>P3V3S4_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_APWROK</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> 3.3v (normally 0v, but I jumped from <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_PCHPWRGD</SIGNAL>)
<SIGNAL>PCH_SUSWARN_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 0v

How should I proceed with this?

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message: Green light turning orange with battery disconnected? Original 85W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message: Green light then turns orange all while battery is disconnected. And yes original charger working on other laptops.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message: I'd also like to add that it does try to load (Apple logo screen with loading bar up to 75%) when both battery and charger and then it restarts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message:
Are you booting from a known good USB/SSD drive?

Don't use comments, make a reply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message:
Tried testing a good USB drive with Install MacOS, but the screen that I get after holding option key shows for a split second and then restarts as well. It was long enough for me to make out that the SSD is being recognized.

This happens with and without the SSD connected and trying to boot from the USB drive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message:
I was told that it was liquid damage, but I am starting not to believe it. None of the white stickers are red, no sign of water or any corrosion on the board. Looks like a completely brand new board. I removed the keyboard connector just now and tried starting it. It does the same thing.

Am I being trolled?

Can the daughter board for the HDMI/memory card slots be disconnected for the system to run? It currently is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message:
You can take everything off and it will run, just fans will be on high and it may run slow. These boards have the shitty shutdown problems like <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
Make sure <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> is at 3.4V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message:
I see.

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is at 3.38v. Check.

Possibly a bad SMC is causing this board to fail?

EDIT: I also notice the CPU is scorching hot. Not too sure if this is normal, but the fan isn't running at full speed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message: Nope, it is probably the usual 3662/3787 shut down issue. These are hopeless if that happens, sorry. Unless there is some other history to this board this one is hopeless.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boot Logo, Quits, Repeats Every 5 Seconds
threads.message: Much appreciated for your time. Thanks, dukefawks.
